title: Part 2.1 Step 3 - Export FBX
body:
Task: Export to FBX

Steps
-----
1. Open cube_smooth.ma
2. Export Selection as FBX
3. Name: cube_final.fbx

----------
cube_final.fbx file

title: Part 2.1 Step 2 - Apply smoothing
body:

Steps
-----
1. Open cube_base.ma
2. Apply smooth (2 levels)
3. Save as cube_smooth.ma

-----

3. Move to Y=2
4. Save as test_sphere.ma

body:

title: Part 1.1 Step 2 - Install Blender 3.6
body:

-----

3. Run installer
4. Verify installation

Blender 3.6 installed and running

title: Part 1.1 Step 1 - Install Maya 2024
body:

Steps
-----
1. Go to https://www.autodesk.com/education/free-software/maya
2. Create education account
3. Download Maya 2024
4. Run installer with defaults
5. Verify installation

Deliverable

title: Part 3.4 - Produce first shots

milestone.title: Week 2: Foundation Skills
milestone.description: Master basic modeling, UV mapping, and shaders. Parts 3-4.

body:
Task: Render Shot Sequence

Steps
-----
1. Set up camera
   - Create camera
   - Focal length: 35mm
   - Position for wide shot

2. Configure render settings
   - Resolution: 1920x1080
   - Frame range: 1-100
   - Sampling: AA samples = 3

3. Render sequence
   - Rendering menu > Render Sequence
   - Output: renders/shot_001/
   - Format: PNG sequence

Verification
-----------
- 100 PNG files created
- Each file is 1920x1080
- Consistent lighting across frames

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 3.3 - Build environment

milestone.title: Week 2: Foundation Skills
milestone.description: Master basic modeling, UV mapping, and shaders. Parts 3-4.

body:
Task: Environment Assembly

Steps
-----
1. Create terrain
   - Create plane: 100x100 units
   - Subdivide to 50x50
   - Sculpt Geometry Tool for hills

2. Instance trees
   - Import tree model
   - Create 20 instances
   - Use Modify > Snap to grid
   - Randomize rotation and scale (80-120%)

3. Generate lightmap
   - Select terrain
   - Lighting/Shading menu > Transfer Maps
   - Output: Ambient Occlusion
   - Resolution: 2048x2048

Verification
-----------
- 20 tree instances placed
- Lightmap texture generated
- Scene runs at 30+ fps in viewport

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 3.2 - Develop animation skills

milestone.title: Week 2: Foundation Skills
milestone.description: Master basic modeling, UV mapping, and shaders. Parts 3-4.

body:
Task: Character Walk Cycle

Steps
-----
1. Create simple biped
   - Use Maya Quick Rig
   - Skeleton menu > Quick Rig
   - Auto-rig with default settings

2. Set walk cycle poses
   - Frame 1: Contact pose (left foot forward)
   - Frame 6: Down pose
   - Frame 12: Passing pose
   - Frame 18: Up pose
   - Frame 24: Contact pose (right foot forward)

3. Create cycle
   - Graph Editor: Post Infinity > Cycle
   - Ensure seamless loop

4. Bake and export
   - Edit menu > Keys > Bake Simulation
   - Export as FBX with baked animation

Verification
-----------
- Walk cycle loops seamlessly
- No foot sliding
- 24 frames total

Reference
---------
Walk cycle tutorial: https://www.animatorisland.com/51-great-animation-exercises-to-master/

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 3.1 - Create detailed models

milestone.title: Week 2: Foundation Skills
milestone.description: Master basic modeling, UV mapping, and shaders. Parts 3-4.

body:
Task: Model Detailed Tree

Steps
-----
1. Create trunk base
   - Create cylinder: radius=1, height=10
   - Add 8 edge loops vertically
   - Select every other edge loop
   - Scale outward slightly for organic shape

2. Add branches
   - Duplicate trunk cylinder
   - Scale to 30% size
   - Position at trunk midpoint
   - Rotate 45 degrees
   - Duplicate and position 5 more branches

3. Create LOD versions
   - LOD0: Full detail (2500 polygons)
   - LOD1: Reduce to 1000 polygons
   - LOD2: Reduce to 500 polygons
   - LOD3: Reduce to 200 polygons
   - LOD4: Reduce to 50 polygons

4. Export sequence
   - Select each LOD
   - Export as: tree_LOD0.obj through tree_LOD4.obj

Verification
-----------
- Polygon counts match specifications
- Silhouette maintained across LODs
- Files export without errors

Reference
---------
LOD workflow: https://docs.unrealengine.com/5.0/en-US/creating-and-using-lods-in-unreal-engine/

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 2.4 - Set up rendering pipeline

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: Render Pipeline Setup

Steps
-----
1. Configure render layers
   - Windows > Rendering Editors > Render Setup
   - Create new layer: 'beauty'
   - Create new layer: 'shadow'

2. Set output settings
   - Render Settings window
   - Image format: EXR (multichannel)
   - Frame padding: 4
   - File prefix: <Scene>_<Layer>_<Version>

3. Create batch render
   - Save script to shelf:
   ```python
   import maya.cmds as cmds
   cmds.batchRender()
   ```

Verification
-----------
- Render outputs to correct folder
- EXR files contain multiple passes
- Batch script runs successfully

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 2.3 - Learn intermediate tools

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: UV Mapping and Texturing

Steps
-----
1. Create UV map
   - Create a cube
   - UV menu > UV Editor
   - Select all faces
   - UV menu > Automatic mapping

2. Apply checker pattern
   - Hypershade window
   - Create > 2D Textures > Checker
   - Assign to cube

3. Render preview
   - Arnold menu > Render
   - Resolution: 1920x1080
   - Save as: uv_test_render.png

Verification
-----------
- Checker pattern displays evenly
- No stretching or distortion
- Each face shows 4x4 checker squares

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files

title: Part 2.2 - Refine animation techniques

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: Create Basic Animation

Steps
-----
1. Set up animation timeline
   - Set timeline to 1-120 frames
   - Frame rate: 24fps

2. Create bouncing ball animation
   - Create sphere at Y=10
   - Frame 1: Set keyframe (press S)
   - Frame 24: Move to Y=0, set keyframe
   - Frame 48: Move to Y=7, set keyframe
   - Frame 72: Move to Y=0, set keyframe
   - Frame 96: Move to Y=4, set keyframe
   - Frame 120: Move to Y=0, set keyframe

3. Adjust animation curves
   - Windows > Animation Editors > Graph Editor
   - Select all keyframes
   - Tangents menu > Auto

4. Export animation
   - File > Export All
   - Type: FBX
   - Options: Check 'Animation'
   - Name: bouncing_ball_anim.fbx

Verification
-----------
- Ball bounces naturally
- Animation plays at 24fps
- FBX contains animation data

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 2.1 - Expand basic skills

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: Create and Modify 3D Geometry

Steps
-----
1. Create base geometry in Maya
   - Open Maya
   - Create menu > Polygon Primitives > Cube
   - Channel Box: Scale X, Y, Z = 10

2. Add edge loops
   - Select cube
   - Mesh Tools menu > Insert Edge Loop
   - Click and drag to add 3 horizontal loops
   - Add 3 vertical loops

3. Apply subdivision
   - Select cube
   - Mesh menu > Smooth
   - Division levels: 2

4. Export as FBX
   - File menu > Export All
   - File type: FBX export
   - Name: subdivided_cube.fbx

Verification
-----------
- Cube has smooth corners
- Polycount approximately 384 faces
- FBX file size approximately 50KB

Reference
---------
Polygon modeling: https://help.autodesk.com/view/MAYAUL/2024/ENU/?guid=GUID-7A41BD84-8C2F-4E56-9ECC-4C59B849F9B5

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 1.4 - Install advanced toolset

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: Install Rendering Tools

Steps
-----
1. Verify Arnold in Maya
   - Open Maya
   - Windows > Settings/Preferences > Plug-in Manager
   - Confirm 'mtoa.mll' is loaded

2. Download Substance 3D Painter
   - Go to: https://www.adobe.com/products/substance3d-painter.html
   - Start free trial
   - Download installer

3. Configure Arnold render settings
   - Open Maya
   - Windows > Rendering Editors > Render Settings
   - Render Using: Arnold Renderer
   - Image format: EXR
   - Resolution: HD_1080 (1920x1080)

4. Create test render
   - Create a sphere with a light
   - Arnold menu > Render
   - Save image as: test_arnold_render.exr

Verification
-----------
- Arnold renders without errors
- EXR file saved successfully
- Substance Painter launches

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 1.3 - Configure simulation and mocap tools

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: Set Up Simulation Tools

Steps
-----
1. Enable nCloth in Maya
   - Open Maya
   - Windows menu > Settings/Preferences > Plug-in Manager
   - Find 'nCloth.mll'
   - Check both 'Loaded' and 'Auto load'

2. Create test cloth simulation
   - Create menu > Polygon Primitives > Plane
   - Scale to 10 units wide
   - With plane selected: nCloth menu > Create nCloth

3. Add collision object
   - Create menu > Polygon Primitives > Sphere
   - Position below plane (Y = -2)
   - Scale to 3 units
   - With sphere selected: nCloth menu > Create Passive Collider

4. Configure simulation
   - Select time slider
   - Set end frame to 120
   - Playback controls > Set to 'Play every frame'

5. Cache the simulation
   - Select the cloth object
   - nCache menu > Create New Cache
   - Name: cloth_test_cache
   - Click Create

6. Save simulation scene
   - File > Save Scene As
   - Name: cloth_simulation_test.ma

Verification
-----------
- Cloth falls and drapes over sphere
- Cache files created in data/cache/ folder
- Playback is real-time after caching

Documentation
------------
nCloth basics: https://knowledge.autodesk.com/support/maya/learn-explore/caas/CloudHelp/cloudhelp/2024/ENU/Maya-SimulationEffects/files/GUID-59B8C4B6-7CF5-4F7E-9500-91C50D54B63D-htm.html

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 1.2 - Set up Python scripting environment

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: Configure Python Environment

Steps
-----
1. Install Python 3.11
   - Go to: https://www.python.org/downloads/
   - Download Python 3.11 installer
   - Run installer
   - Check 'Add Python to PATH'

2. Verify Python installation
   - Open terminal/command prompt
   - Type: python --version
   - Should display: Python 3.11.x

3. Configure Maya Python path
   - Open Maya
   - Open Script Editor (Windows > General Editors > Script Editor)
   - Switch to Python tab

4. Create cube generation script
   - In Script Editor, type:
   ```python
   import maya.cmds as cmds
   # Create a cube
   cube = cmds.polyCube(width=2, height=2, depth=2)
   # Move it up
   cmds.move(0, 1, 0, cube[0])
   # Add subdivision
   cmds.polySmooth(cube[0], divisions=1)
   ```

5. Save the script
   - File menu (in Script Editor) > Save Script
   - Name: create_cube.py
   - Save to: Documents/maya/scripts/

6. Test script execution
   - Clear scene (File > New Scene)
   - In Script Editor: execfile('create_cube.py')
   - A smoothed cube should appear

Verification
-----------
- Python script runs without errors
- Cube appears at coordinates (0, 1, 0)
- Cube has smooth subdivision

Documentation
------------
Maya Python API: https://help.autodesk.com/view/MAYAUL/2024/ENU/?guid=Maya_SDK_Python_API
Python basics: https://docs.python.org/3.11/tutorial/

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders

title: Part 1.1 - Install software and create first files

milestone.title: Week 1: Installation & First Touch
milestone.description: Complete all software installation and first exercises. Parts 1-2.

body:
Task: Install 3D Software Suite

Steps
-----
1. Download Maya 2024
   - Go to: https://www.autodesk.com/education/free-software/maya
   - Create education account
   - Select Maya 2024
   - Download installer (approximately 2GB)

2. Install Maya
   - Run installer
   - Select default installation path
   - Include Arnold renderer
   - Wait for completion (10-15 minutes)

3. Download Blender 3.6 LTS
   - Go to: https://www.blender.org/download/lts/3-6/
   - Select your operating system
   - Download installer (approximately 200MB)

4. Install Blender
   - Run installer
   - Use default settings
   - Installation time: 2-3 minutes

5. Download Houdini Apprentice
   - Go to: https://www.sidefx.com/download/
   - Create free account
   - Select Houdini Apprentice
   - Download installer (approximately 1.5GB)

6. Create test files
   Maya:
   - Open Maya
   - Create menu > Polygon Primitives > Sphere
   - File menu > Save Scene As
   - Name: test_sphere.ma
   
   Blender:
   - Open Blender
   - Shift+A > Mesh > UV Sphere
   - File menu > Save As
   - Name: test_sphere.blend

Verification
-----------
- All three applications launch without errors
- Test files saved successfully
- File sizes: .ma (~30KB), .blend (~800KB)

Documentation
------------
Maya basics: https://help.autodesk.com/view/MAYAUL/2024/ENU/
Blender manual: https://docs.blender.org/manual/en/3.6/
Houdini foundations: https://www.sidefx.com/tutorials/foundations-overview/

Output Requirements
------------------
- Save all project files
- Take screenshot of completed work
- Export required formats
- Organize in project folders
